segment.source: Create Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps with intuitive and distinctive user interaction experiences that are optimized for touch but are functionally consistent across input devices.
segment.target: Create Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps with intuitive and distinctive user interaction experiences that are optimized for touch but are functionally consistent across input devices.

segment.source: Touch interactions
segment.target: Touch interactions

segment.source: Touch interactions
segment.target: Touch interactions

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Design your app with the expectation that touch will be the primary input method of your users.
segment.target: Design your app with the expectation that touch will be the primary input method of your users.

segment.source: If you use UWP controls, support for touchpad, mouse, and pen/stylus requires no additional programming, because UWP apps provide this for free.
segment.target: If you use UWP controls, support for touchpad, mouse, and pen/stylus requires no additional programming, because UWP apps provide this for free.

segment.source: However, keep in mind that a UI optimized for touch is not always superior to a traditional UI.
segment.target: However, keep in mind that a UI optimized for touch is not always superior to a traditional UI.

segment.source: Both provide advantages and disadvantages that are unique to a technology and application.
segment.target: Both provide advantages and disadvantages that are unique to a technology and application.

segment.source: In the move to a touch-first UI, it is important to understand the core differences between touch (including touchpad), pen/stylus, mouse, and keyboard input.
segment.target: In the move to a touch-first UI, it is important to understand the core differences between touch (including touchpad), pen/stylus, mouse, and keyboard input.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Input
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Input

segment.source: Windows.UI.Core
segment.target: Windows.UI.Core

segment.source: Windows.Devices.Input
segment.target: Windows.Devices.Input

segment.source: Many devices have multi-touch screens that support using one or more fingers (or touch contacts) as input.
segment.target: Many devices have multi-touch screens that support using one or more fingers (or touch contacts) as input.

segment.source: The touch contacts, and their movement, are interpreted as touch gestures and manipulations to support various user interactions.
segment.target: The touch contacts, and their movement, are interpreted as touch gestures and manipulations to support various user interactions.

segment.source: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) includes a number of different mechanisms for handling touch input, enabling you to create an immersive experience that your users can explore with confidence.
segment.target: The Universal Windows Platform (UWP) includes a number of different mechanisms for handling touch input, enabling you to create an immersive experience that your users can explore with confidence.

segment.source: Here, we cover the basics of using touch input in a UWP app.
segment.target: Here, we cover the basics of using touch input in a UWP app.

segment.source: Touch interactions require three things:
segment.target: Touch interactions require three things:

segment.source: A touch-sensitive display.
segment.target: A touch-sensitive display.

segment.source: The direct contact (or proximity to, if the display has proximity sensors and supports hover detection) of one or more fingers on that display.
segment.target: The direct contact (or proximity to, if the display has proximity sensors and supports hover detection) of one or more fingers on that display.

segment.source: Movement of the touch contacts (or lack thereof, based on a time threshold).
segment.target: Movement of the touch contacts (or lack thereof, based on a time threshold).

segment.source: The input data provided by the touch sensor can be:
segment.target: The input data provided by the touch sensor can be:

segment.source: Interpreted as a physical gesture for direct manipulation of one or more UI elements (such as panning, rotating, resizing, or moving).
segment.target: Interpreted as a physical gesture for direct manipulation of one or more UI elements (such as panning, rotating, resizing, or moving).

segment.source: In contrast, interacting with an element through its properties window, dialog box, or other UI affordance is considered indirect manipulation.
segment.target: In contrast, interacting with an element through its properties window, dialog box, or other UI affordance is considered indirect manipulation.

segment.source: Recognized as an alternative input method, such as mouse or pen.
segment.target: Recognized as an alternative input method, such as mouse or pen.

segment.source: Used to complement or modify aspects of other input methods, such as smudging an ink stroke drawn with a pen.
segment.target: Used to complement or modify aspects of other input methods, such as smudging an ink stroke drawn with a pen.

segment.source: Touch input typically involves the direct manipulation of an element on the screen.
segment.target: Touch input typically involves the direct manipulation of an element on the screen.

segment.source: The element responds immediately to any touch contact within its hit test area, and reacts appropriately to any subsequent movement of the touch contacts, including removal.
segment.target: The element responds immediately to any touch contact within its hit test area, and reacts appropriately to any subsequent movement of the touch contacts, including removal.

segment.source: Custom touch gestures and interactions should be designed carefully.
segment.target: Custom touch gestures and interactions should be designed carefully.

segment.source: They should be intuitive, responsive, and discoverable, and they should let users explore your app with confidence.
segment.target: They should be intuitive, responsive, and discoverable, and they should let users explore your app with confidence.

segment.source: Ensure that app functionality is exposed consistently across every supported input device type.
segment.target: Ensure that app functionality is exposed consistently across every supported input device type.

segment.source: If necessary, use some form of indirect input mode, such as text input for keyboard interactions, or UI affordances for mouse and pen.
segment.target: If necessary, use some form of indirect input mode, such as text input for keyboard interactions, or UI affordances for mouse and pen.

segment.source: Remember that traditional input devices (such as mouse and keyboard), are familiar and appealing to many users.
segment.target: Remember that traditional input devices (such as mouse and keyboard), are familiar and appealing to many users.

segment.source: They can offer speed, accuracy, and tactile feedback that touch might not.
segment.target: They can offer speed, accuracy, and tactile feedback that touch might not.

segment.source: Providing unique and distinctive interaction experiences for all input devices will support the widest range of capabilities and preferences, appeal to the broadest possible audience, and attract more customers to your app.
segment.target: Providing unique and distinctive interaction experiences for all input devices will support the widest range of capabilities and preferences, appeal to the broadest possible audience, and attract more customers to your app.

segment.source: Compare touch interaction requirements
segment.target: Compare touch interaction requirements

segment.source: The following table shows some of the differences between input devices that you should consider when you design touch-optimized UWP apps.
segment.target: The following table shows some of the differences between input devices that you should consider when you design touch-optimized UWP apps.

segment.source: Factor
segment.target: Factor

segment.source: Touch interactions
segment.target: Touch interactions

segment.source: Mouse, keyboard, pen/stylus interactions
segment.target: Mouse, keyboard, pen/stylus interactions

segment.source: Touchpad
segment.target: Touchpad

segment.source: Precision
segment.target: Precision

segment.source: The contact area of a fingertip is greater than a single x-y coordinate, which increases the chances of unintended command activations.
segment.target: The contact area of a fingertip is greater than a single x-y coordinate, which increases the chances of unintended command activations.

segment.source: The mouse and pen/stylus supply a precise x-y coordinate.
segment.target: The mouse and pen/stylus supply a precise x-y coordinate.

segment.source: Same as mouse.
segment.target: Same as mouse.

segment.source: The shape of the contact area changes throughout the movement.
segment.target: The shape of the contact area changes throughout the movement.

segment.source: Mouse movements and pen/stylus strokes supply precise x-y coordinates.
segment.target: Mouse movements and pen/stylus strokes supply precise x-y coordinates.

segment.source: Keyboard focus is explicit.
segment.target: Keyboard focus is explicit.

segment.source: Same as mouse.
segment.target: Same as mouse.

segment.source: There is no mouse cursor to assist with targeting.
segment.target: There is no mouse cursor to assist with targeting.

segment.source: The mouse cursor, pen/stylus cursor, and keyboard focus all assist with targeting.
segment.target: The mouse cursor, pen/stylus cursor, and keyboard focus all assist with targeting.

segment.source: Same as mouse.
segment.target: Same as mouse.

segment.source: Human anatomy
segment.target: Human anatomy

segment.source: Fingertip movements are imprecise, because a straight-line motion with one or more fingers is difficult.
segment.target: Fingertip movements are imprecise, because a straight-line motion with one or more fingers is difficult.

segment.source: This is due to the curvature of hand joints and the number of joints involved in the motion.
segment.target: This is due to the curvature of hand joints and the number of joints involved in the motion.

segment.source: It's easier to perform a straight-line motion with the mouse or pen/stylus because the hand that controls them travels a shorter physical distance than the cursor on the screen.
segment.target: It's easier to perform a straight-line motion with the mouse or pen/stylus because the hand that controls them travels a shorter physical distance than the cursor on the screen.

segment.source: Same as mouse.
segment.target: Same as mouse.

segment.source: Some areas on the touch surface of a display device can be difficult to reach due to finger posture and the user's grip on the device.
segment.target: Some areas on the touch surface of a display device can be difficult to reach due to finger posture and the user's grip on the device.

segment.source: The mouse and pen/stylus can reach any part of the screen while any control should be accessible by the keyboard through tab order.
segment.target: The mouse and pen/stylus can reach any part of the screen while any control should be accessible by the keyboard through tab order.

segment.source: Finger posture and grip can be an issue.
segment.target: Finger posture and grip can be an issue.

segment.source: Objects might be obscured by one or more fingertips or the user's hand.
segment.target: Objects might be obscured by one or more fingertips or the user's hand.

segment.source: This is known as occlusion.
segment.target: This is known as occlusion.

segment.source: Indirect input devices do not cause occlusion.
segment.target: Indirect input devices do not cause occlusion.

segment.source: Same as mouse.
segment.target: Same as mouse.

segment.source: Object state
segment.target: Object state

segment.source: Touch uses a two-state model: the touch surface of a display device is either touched (on) or not (off).
segment.target: Touch uses a two-state model: the touch surface of a display device is either touched (on) or not (off).

segment.source: There is no hover state that can trigger additional visual feedback.
segment.target: There is no hover state that can trigger additional visual feedback.

segment.source: A mouse, pen/stylus, and keyboard all expose a three-state model: up (off), down (on), and hover (focus).
segment.target: A mouse, pen/stylus, and keyboard all expose a three-state model: up (off), down (on), and hover (focus).

segment.source: Hover lets users explore and learn through tooltips associated with UI elements.
segment.target: Hover lets users explore and learn through tooltips associated with UI elements.

segment.source: Hover and focus effects can relay which objects are interactive and also help with targeting.
segment.target: Hover and focus effects can relay which objects are interactive and also help with targeting.

segment.source: Same as mouse.
segment.target: Same as mouse.

segment.source: Rich interaction
segment.target: Rich interaction

segment.source: Supports multi-touch: multiple input points (fingertips) on a touch surface.
segment.target: Supports multi-touch: multiple input points (fingertips) on a touch surface.

segment.source: Supports a single input point.
segment.target: Supports a single input point.

segment.source: Same as touch.
segment.target: Same as touch.

segment.source: Supports direct manipulation of objects through gestures such as tapping, dragging, sliding, pinching, and rotating.
segment.target: Supports direct manipulation of objects through gestures such as tapping, dragging, sliding, pinching, and rotating.

segment.source: No support for direct manipulation as mouse, pen/stylus, and keyboard are indirect input devices.
segment.target: No support for direct manipulation as mouse, pen/stylus, and keyboard are indirect input devices.

segment.source: Same as mouse.
segment.target: Same as mouse.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Indirect input has had the benefit of more than 25 years of refinement.
segment.target: Indirect input has had the benefit of more than 25 years of refinement.

segment.source: Features such as hover-triggered tooltips have been designed to solve UI exploration specifically for touchpad, mouse, pen/stylus, and keyboard input.
segment.target: Features such as hover-triggered tooltips have been designed to solve UI exploration specifically for touchpad, mouse, pen/stylus, and keyboard input.

segment.source: UI features like this have been re-designed for the rich experience provided by touch input, without compromising the user experience for these other devices.
segment.target: UI features like this have been re-designed for the rich experience provided by touch input, without compromising the user experience for these other devices.

segment.source: Use touch feedback
segment.target: Use touch feedback

segment.source: Appropriate visual feedback during interactions with your app helps users recognize, learn, and adapt to how their interactions are interpreted by both the app and Windows 8.
segment.target: Appropriate visual feedback during interactions with your app helps users recognize, learn, and adapt to how their interactions are interpreted by both the app and Windows 8.

segment.source: Visual feedback can indicate successful interactions, relay system status, improve the sense of control, reduce errors, help users understand the system and input device, and encourage interaction.
segment.target: Visual feedback can indicate successful interactions, relay system status, improve the sense of control, reduce errors, help users understand the system and input device, and encourage interaction.

segment.source: Visual feedback is critical when the user relies on touch input for activities that require accuracy and precision based on location.
segment.target: Visual feedback is critical when the user relies on touch input for activities that require accuracy and precision based on location.

segment.source: Display feedback whenever and wherever touch input is detected, to help the user understand any custom targeting rules that are defined by your app and its controls.
segment.target: Display feedback whenever and wherever touch input is detected, to help the user understand any custom targeting rules that are defined by your app and its controls.

segment.source: Targeting
segment.target: Targeting

segment.source: Targeting is optimized through:
segment.target: Targeting is optimized through:

segment.source: Touch target sizes
segment.target: Touch target sizes

segment.source: Clear size guidelines ensure that applications provide a comfortable UI that contains objects and controls that are easy and safe to target.
segment.target: Clear size guidelines ensure that applications provide a comfortable UI that contains objects and controls that are easy and safe to target.

segment.source: Contact geometry
segment.target: Contact geometry

segment.source: The entire contact area of the finger determines the most likely target object.
segment.target: The entire contact area of the finger determines the most likely target object.

segment.source: Scrubbing
segment.target: Scrubbing

segment.source: Items within a group are easily re-targeted by dragging the finger between them (for example, radio buttons).
segment.target: Items within a group are easily re-targeted by dragging the finger between them (for example, radio buttons).

segment.source: The current item is activated when the touch is released.
segment.target: The current item is activated when the touch is released.

segment.source: Rocking
segment.target: Rocking

segment.source: Densely packed items (for example, hyperlinks) are easily re-targeted by pressing the finger down and, without sliding, rocking it back and forth over the items.
segment.target: Densely packed items (for example, hyperlinks) are easily re-targeted by pressing the finger down and, without sliding, rocking it back and forth over the items.

segment.source: Due to occlusion, the current item is identified through a tooltip or the status bar and is activated when the touch is released.
segment.target: Due to occlusion, the current item is identified through a tooltip or the status bar and is activated when the touch is released.

segment.source: Accuracy
segment.target: Accuracy

segment.source: Design for sloppy interactions by using:
segment.target: Design for sloppy interactions by using:

segment.source: Snap-points that can make it easier to stop at desired locations when users interact with content.
segment.target: Snap-points that can make it easier to stop at desired locations when users interact with content.

segment.source: Directional "rails" that can assist with vertical or horizontal panning, even when the hand moves in a slight arc.
segment.target: Directional "rails" that can assist with vertical or horizontal panning, even when the hand moves in a slight arc.

segment.source: For more information, see Guidelines for panning.
segment.target: For more information, see Guidelines for panning.

segment.source: Occlusion
segment.target: Occlusion

segment.source: Finger and hand occlusion is avoided through:
segment.target: Finger and hand occlusion is avoided through:

segment.source: Size and positioning of UI
segment.target: Size and positioning of UI

segment.source: Make UI elements big enough so that they cannot be completely covered by a fingertip contact area.
segment.target: Make UI elements big enough so that they cannot be completely covered by a fingertip contact area.

segment.source: Position menus and pop-ups above the contact area whenever possible.
segment.target: Position menus and pop-ups above the contact area whenever possible.

segment.source: Tooltips
segment.target: Tooltips

segment.source: Show tooltips when a user maintains finger contact on an object.
segment.target: Show tooltips when a user maintains finger contact on an object.

segment.source: This is useful for describing object functionality.
segment.target: This is useful for describing object functionality.

segment.source: The user can drag the fingertip off the object to avoid invoking the tooltip.
segment.target: The user can drag the fingertip off the object to avoid invoking the tooltip.

segment.source: For small objects, offset tooltips so they are not covered by the fingertip contact area.
segment.target: For small objects, offset tooltips so they are not covered by the fingertip contact area.

segment.source: This is helpful for targeting.
segment.target: This is helpful for targeting.

segment.source: Handles for precision
segment.target: Handles for precision

segment.source: Where precision is required (for example, text selection), provide selection handles that are offset to improve accuracy.
segment.target: Where precision is required (for example, text selection), provide selection handles that are offset to improve accuracy.

segment.source: For more information, see Guidelines for selecting text and images (Windows Runtime apps).
segment.target: For more information, see Guidelines for selecting text and images (Windows Runtime apps).

segment.source: Timing
segment.target: Timing

segment.source: Avoid timed mode changes in favor of direct manipulation.
segment.target: Avoid timed mode changes in favor of direct manipulation.

segment.source: Direct manipulation simulates the direct, real-time physical handling of an object.
segment.target: Direct manipulation simulates the direct, real-time physical handling of an object.

segment.source: The object responds as the fingers are moved.
segment.target: The object responds as the fingers are moved.

segment.source: A timed interaction, on the other hand, occurs after a touch interaction.
segment.target: A timed interaction, on the other hand, occurs after a touch interaction.

segment.source: Timed interactions typically depend on invisible thresholds like time, distance, or speed to determine what command to perform.
segment.target: Timed interactions typically depend on invisible thresholds like time, distance, or speed to determine what command to perform.

segment.source: Timed interactions have no visual feedback until the system performs the action.
segment.target: Timed interactions have no visual feedback until the system performs the action.

segment.source: Direct manipulation provides a number of benefits over timed interactions:
segment.target: Direct manipulation provides a number of benefits over timed interactions:

segment.source: Instant visual feedback during interactions make users feel more engaged, confident, and in control.
segment.target: Instant visual feedback during interactions make users feel more engaged, confident, and in control.

segment.source: Direct manipulations make it safer to explore a system because they are reversible—users can easily step back through their actions in a logical and intuitive manner.
segment.target: Direct manipulations make it safer to explore a system because they are reversible—users can easily step back through their actions in a logical and intuitive manner.

segment.source: Interactions that directly affect objects and mimic real world interactions are more intuitive, discoverable, and memorable.
segment.target: Interactions that directly affect objects and mimic real world interactions are more intuitive, discoverable, and memorable.

segment.source: They don't rely on obscure or abstract interactions.
segment.target: They don't rely on obscure or abstract interactions.

segment.source: Timed interactions can be difficult to perform, as users must reach arbitrary and invisible thresholds.
segment.target: Timed interactions can be difficult to perform, as users must reach arbitrary and invisible thresholds.

segment.source: In addition, the following are strongly recommended:
segment.target: In addition, the following are strongly recommended:

segment.source: Manipulations should not be distinguished by the number of fingers used.
segment.target: Manipulations should not be distinguished by the number of fingers used.

segment.source: Interactions should support compound manipulations.
segment.target: Interactions should support compound manipulations.

segment.source: For example, pinch to zoom while dragging the fingers to pan.
segment.target: For example, pinch to zoom while dragging the fingers to pan.

segment.source: Interactions should not be distinguished by time.
segment.target: Interactions should not be distinguished by time.

segment.source: The same interaction should have the same outcome regardless of the time taken to perform it.
segment.target: The same interaction should have the same outcome regardless of the time taken to perform it.

segment.source: Time-based activations introduce mandatory delays for users and detract from both the immersive nature of direct manipulation and the perception of system responsiveness.
segment.target: Time-based activations introduce mandatory delays for users and detract from both the immersive nature of direct manipulation and the perception of system responsiveness.

segment.source: Note An exception to this is where you use specific timed interactions to assist in learning and exploration (for example, press and hold).
segment.target: Note An exception to this is where you use specific timed interactions to assist in learning and exploration (for example, press and hold).

segment.source: Appropriate descriptions and visual cues have a great effect on the use of advanced interactions.
segment.target: Appropriate descriptions and visual cues have a great effect on the use of advanced interactions.

segment.source: App views
segment.target: App views

segment.source: Tweak the user interaction experience through the pan/scroll and zoom settings of your app views.
segment.target: Tweak the user interaction experience through the pan/scroll and zoom settings of your app views.

segment.source: An app view dictates how a user accesses and manipulates your app and its content.
segment.target: An app view dictates how a user accesses and manipulates your app and its content.

segment.source: Views also provide behaviors such as inertia, content boundary bounce, and snap points.
segment.target: Views also provide behaviors such as inertia, content boundary bounce, and snap points.

segment.source: Pan and scroll settings of the ScrollViewer control dictate how users navigate within a single view, when the content of the view doesn't fit within the viewport.
segment.target: Pan and scroll settings of the ScrollViewer control dictate how users navigate within a single view, when the content of the view doesn't fit within the viewport.

segment.source: A single view can be, for example, a page of a magazine or book, the folder structure of a computer, a library of documents, or a photo album.
segment.target: A single view can be, for example, a page of a magazine or book, the folder structure of a computer, a library of documents, or a photo album.

segment.source: Zoom settings apply to both optical zoom (supported by the ScrollViewer control) and the Semantic Zoom control.
segment.target: Zoom settings apply to both optical zoom (supported by the ScrollViewer control) and the Semantic Zoom control.

segment.source: Semantic Zoom is a touch-optimized technique for presenting and navigating large sets of related data or content within a single view.
segment.target: Semantic Zoom is a touch-optimized technique for presenting and navigating large sets of related data or content within a single view.

segment.source: It works by using two distinct modes of classification, or zoom levels.
segment.target: It works by using two distinct modes of classification, or zoom levels.

segment.source: This is analogous to panning and scrolling within a single view.
segment.target: This is analogous to panning and scrolling within a single view.

segment.source: Panning and scrolling can be used in conjunction with Semantic Zoom.
segment.target: Panning and scrolling can be used in conjunction with Semantic Zoom.

segment.source: Use app views and events to modify the pan/scroll and zoom behaviors.
segment.target: Use app views and events to modify the pan/scroll and zoom behaviors.

segment.source: This can provide a smoother interaction experience than is possible through the handling of pointer and gesture events.
segment.target: This can provide a smoother interaction experience than is possible through the handling of pointer and gesture events.

segment.source: For more info about app views, see Controls, layouts, and text.
segment.target: For more info about app views, see Controls, layouts, and text.

segment.source: Custom touch interactions
segment.target: Custom touch interactions

segment.source: If you implement your own interaction support, keep in mind that users expect an intuitive experience involving direct interaction with the UI elements in your app.
segment.target: If you implement your own interaction support, keep in mind that users expect an intuitive experience involving direct interaction with the UI elements in your app.

segment.source: We recommend that you model your custom interactions on the platform control libraries to keep things consistent and discoverable.
segment.target: We recommend that you model your custom interactions on the platform control libraries to keep things consistent and discoverable.

segment.source: The controls in these libraries provide the full user interaction experience, including standard interactions, animated physics effects, visual feedback, and accessibility.
segment.target: The controls in these libraries provide the full user interaction experience, including standard interactions, animated physics effects, visual feedback, and accessibility.

segment.source: Create custom interactions only if there is a clear, well-defined requirement and basic interactions don't support your scenario.
segment.target: Create custom interactions only if there is a clear, well-defined requirement and basic interactions don't support your scenario.

segment.source: To provide customized touch support, you can handle various UIElement events.
segment.target: To provide customized touch support, you can handle various UIElement events.

segment.source: These events are grouped into three levels of abstraction.
segment.target: These events are grouped into three levels of abstraction.

segment.source: Static gesture events are triggered after an interaction is complete.
segment.target: Static gesture events are triggered after an interaction is complete.

segment.source: Gesture events include Tapped, DoubleTapped, RightTapped, and Holding.
segment.target: Gesture events include Tapped, DoubleTapped, RightTapped, and Holding.

segment.source: You can disable gesture events on specific elements by setting IsTapEnabled, IsDoubleTapEnabled, IsRightTapEnabled, and IsHoldingEnabled to false.
segment.target: You can disable gesture events on specific elements by setting IsTapEnabled, IsDoubleTapEnabled, IsRightTapEnabled, and IsHoldingEnabled to false.

segment.source: Pointer events such as PointerPressed and PointerMoved provide low-level details for each touch contact, including pointer motion and the ability to distinguish press and release events.
segment.target: Pointer events such as PointerPressed and PointerMoved provide low-level details for each touch contact, including pointer motion and the ability to distinguish press and release events.

segment.source: A pointer is a generic input type with a unified event mechanism.
segment.target: A pointer is a generic input type with a unified event mechanism.

segment.source: It exposes basic info, such as screen position, on the active input source, which can be touch, touchpad, mouse, or pen.
segment.target: It exposes basic info, such as screen position, on the active input source, which can be touch, touchpad, mouse, or pen.

segment.source: Manipulation gesture events, such as ManipulationStarted, indicate an ongoing interaction.
segment.target: Manipulation gesture events, such as ManipulationStarted, indicate an ongoing interaction.

segment.source: They start firing when the user touches an element and continue until the user lifts their finger(s), or the manipulation is canceled.
segment.target: They start firing when the user touches an element and continue until the user lifts their finger(s), or the manipulation is canceled.

segment.source: Manipulation events include multi-touch interactions such as zooming, panning, or rotating, and interactions that use inertia and velocity data such as dragging.
segment.target: Manipulation events include multi-touch interactions such as zooming, panning, or rotating, and interactions that use inertia and velocity data such as dragging.

segment.source: The information provided by the manipulation events doesn't identify the form of the interaction that was performed, but rather includes data such as position, translation delta, and velocity.
segment.target: The information provided by the manipulation events doesn't identify the form of the interaction that was performed, but rather includes data such as position, translation delta, and velocity.

segment.source: You can use this touch data to determine the type of interaction that should be performed.
segment.target: You can use this touch data to determine the type of interaction that should be performed.

segment.source: Here is the basic set of touch gestures supported by the UWP.
segment.target: Here is the basic set of touch gestures supported by the UWP.

segment.source: Name
segment.target: Name

segment.source: Type
segment.target: Type

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Tap
segment.target: Tap

segment.source: Static gesture
segment.target: Static gesture

segment.source: One finger touches the screen and lifts up.
segment.target: One finger touches the screen and lifts up.

segment.source: Press and hold
segment.target: Press and hold

segment.source: Static gesture
segment.target: Static gesture

segment.source: One finger touches the screen and stays in place.
segment.target: One finger touches the screen and stays in place.

segment.source: Slide
segment.target: Slide

segment.source: Manipulation gesture
segment.target: Manipulation gesture

segment.source: One or more fingers touch the screen and move in the same direction.
segment.target: One or more fingers touch the screen and move in the same direction.

segment.source: Swipe
segment.target: Swipe

segment.source: Manipulation gesture
segment.target: Manipulation gesture

segment.source: One or more fingers touch the screen and move a short distance in the same direction.
segment.target: One or more fingers touch the screen and move a short distance in the same direction.

segment.source: Turn
segment.target: Turn

segment.source: Manipulation gesture
segment.target: Manipulation gesture

segment.source: Two or more fingers touch the screen and move in a clockwise or counter-clockwise arc.
segment.target: Two or more fingers touch the screen and move in a clockwise or counter-clockwise arc.

segment.source: Pinch
segment.target: Pinch

segment.source: Manipulation gesture
segment.target: Manipulation gesture

segment.source: Two or more fingers touch the screen and move closer together.
segment.target: Two or more fingers touch the screen and move closer together.

segment.source: Stretch
segment.target: Stretch

segment.source: Manipulation gesture
segment.target: Manipulation gesture

segment.source: Two or more fingers touch the screen and move farther apart.
segment.target: Two or more fingers touch the screen and move farther apart.

segment.source: Gesture events
segment.target: Gesture events

segment.source: For details about individual controls, see Controls list.
segment.target: For details about individual controls, see Controls list.

segment.source: Pointer events
segment.target: Pointer events

segment.source: Pointer events are raised by a variety of active input sources, including touch, touchpad, pen, and mouse (they replace traditional mouse events.)
segment.target: Pointer events are raised by a variety of active input sources, including touch, touchpad, pen, and mouse (they replace traditional mouse events.)

segment.source: Pointer events are based on a single input point (finger, pen tip, mouse cursor) and do not support velocity-based interactions.
segment.target: Pointer events are based on a single input point (finger, pen tip, mouse cursor) and do not support velocity-based interactions.

segment.source: Here is a list of pointer events and their related event argument.
segment.target: Here is a list of pointer events and their related event argument.

segment.source: Event or class
segment.target: Event or class

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: PointerPressed
segment.target: PointerPressed

segment.source: Occurs when a single finger touches the screen.
segment.target: Occurs when a single finger touches the screen.

segment.source: PointerReleased
segment.target: PointerReleased

segment.source: Occurs when that same touch contact is lifted.
segment.target: Occurs when that same touch contact is lifted.

segment.source: PointerMoved
segment.target: PointerMoved

segment.source: Occurs when the pointer is dragged across the screen.
segment.target: Occurs when the pointer is dragged across the screen.

segment.source: PointerEntered
segment.target: PointerEntered

segment.source: Occurs when a pointer enters the hit test area of an element.
segment.target: Occurs when a pointer enters the hit test area of an element.

segment.source: PointerExited
segment.target: PointerExited

segment.source: Occurs when a pointer exits the hit test area of an element.
segment.target: Occurs when a pointer exits the hit test area of an element.

segment.source: PointerCanceled
segment.target: PointerCanceled

segment.source: Occurs when a touch contact is abnormally lost.
segment.target: Occurs when a touch contact is abnormally lost.

segment.source: PointerCaptureLost
segment.target: PointerCaptureLost

segment.source: Occurs when a pointer capture is taken by another element.
segment.target: Occurs when a pointer capture is taken by another element.

segment.source: PointerWheelChanged
segment.target: PointerWheelChanged

segment.source: Occurs when the delta value of a mouse wheel changes.
segment.target: Occurs when the delta value of a mouse wheel changes.

segment.source: PointerRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: PointerRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: Provides data for all pointer events.
segment.target: Provides data for all pointer events.

segment.source: The following example shows how to use the PointerPressed, PointerReleased, and PointerExited events to handle a tap interaction on a Rectangle object.
segment.target: The following example shows how to use the PointerPressed, PointerReleased, and PointerExited events to handle a tap interaction on a Rectangle object.

segment.source: First, a Rectangle named is created in Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).
segment.target: First, a Rectangle named is created in Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).

segment.source: Next, listeners for the PointerPressed, PointerReleased, and PointerExited events are specified.
segment.target: Next, listeners for the PointerPressed, PointerReleased, and PointerExited events are specified.

segment.source: Finally, the PointerPressed event handler increases the Height and Width of the Rectangle, while the PointerReleased and PointerExited event handlers set the Height and Width back to their starting values.
segment.target: Finally, the PointerPressed event handler increases the Height and Width of the Rectangle, while the PointerReleased and PointerExited event handlers set the Height and Width back to their starting values.

segment.source: Manipulation events
segment.target: Manipulation events

segment.source: Use manipulation events if you need to support multiple finger interactions in your app, or interactions that require velocity data.
segment.target: Use manipulation events if you need to support multiple finger interactions in your app, or interactions that require velocity data.

segment.source: You can use manipulation events to detect interactions such as drag, zoom, and hold.
segment.target: You can use manipulation events to detect interactions such as drag, zoom, and hold.

segment.source: Here is a list of manipulation events and related event arguments.
segment.target: Here is a list of manipulation events and related event arguments.

segment.source: Event or class
segment.target: Event or class

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: ManipulationStarting event
segment.target: ManipulationStarting event

segment.source: Occurs when the manipulation processor is first created.
segment.target: Occurs when the manipulation processor is first created.

segment.source: ManipulationStarted event
segment.target: ManipulationStarted event

segment.source: Occurs when an input device begins a manipulation on the UIElement.
segment.target: Occurs when an input device begins a manipulation on the UIElement.

segment.source: ManipulationDelta event
segment.target: ManipulationDelta event

segment.source: Occurs when the input device changes position during a manipulation.
segment.target: Occurs when the input device changes position during a manipulation.

segment.source: ManipulationInertiaStarting event
segment.target: ManipulationInertiaStarting event

segment.source: Occurs when the input device loses contact with the UIElement object during a manipulation and inertia begins.
segment.target: Occurs when the input device loses contact with the UIElement object during a manipulation and inertia begins.

segment.source: ManipulationCompleted event
segment.target: ManipulationCompleted event

segment.source: Occurs when a manipulation and inertia on the UIElement are complete.
segment.target: Occurs when a manipulation and inertia on the UIElement are complete.

segment.source: ManipulationStartingRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: ManipulationStartingRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: Provides data for the ManipulationStarting event.
segment.target: Provides data for the ManipulationStarting event.

segment.source: ManipulationStartedRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: ManipulationStartedRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: Provides data for the ManipulationStarted event.
segment.target: Provides data for the ManipulationStarted event.

segment.source: ManipulationDeltaRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: ManipulationDeltaRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: Provides data for the ManipulationDelta event.
segment.target: Provides data for the ManipulationDelta event.

segment.source: ManipulationInertiaStartingRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: ManipulationInertiaStartingRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: Provides data for the ManipulationInertiaStarting event.
segment.target: Provides data for the ManipulationInertiaStarting event.

segment.source: ManipulationVelocities
segment.target: ManipulationVelocities

segment.source: Describes the speed at which manipulations occur.
segment.target: Describes the speed at which manipulations occur.

segment.source: ManipulationCompletedRoutedEventArgs
segment.target: ManipulationCompletedRoutedEventArgs

segment.source: Provides data for the ManipulationCompleted event.
segment.target: Provides data for the ManipulationCompleted event.

segment.source: A gesture consists of a series of manipulation events.
segment.target: A gesture consists of a series of manipulation events.

segment.source: Each gesture starts with a ManipulationStarted event, such as when a user touches the screen.
segment.target: Each gesture starts with a ManipulationStarted event, such as when a user touches the screen.

segment.source: Next, one or more ManipulationDelta events are fired.
segment.target: Next, one or more ManipulationDelta events are fired.

segment.source: For example, if you touch the screen and then drag your finger across the screen.
segment.target: For example, if you touch the screen and then drag your finger across the screen.

segment.source: Finally, a ManipulationCompleted event is raised when the interaction finishes.
segment.target: Finally, a ManipulationCompleted event is raised when the interaction finishes.

segment.source: Note If you don't have a touch-screen monitor, you can test your manipulation event code in the simulator using a mouse and mouse wheel interface.
segment.target: Note If you don't have a touch-screen monitor, you can test your manipulation event code in the simulator using a mouse and mouse wheel interface.

segment.source: The following example shows how to use the ManipulationDelta events to handle a slide interaction on a Rectangle and move it across the screen.
segment.target: The following example shows how to use the ManipulationDelta events to handle a slide interaction on a Rectangle and move it across the screen.

segment.source: First, a Rectangle named is created in XAML with a Height and Width of 200.
segment.target: First, a Rectangle named is created in XAML with a Height and Width of 200.

segment.source: Next, a global TranslateTransform named is created for translating the Rectangle.
segment.target: Next, a global TranslateTransform named is created for translating the Rectangle.

segment.source: A ManipulationDelta event listener is specified on the Rectangle, and is added to the RenderTransform of the Rectangle.
segment.target: A ManipulationDelta event listener is specified on the Rectangle, and is added to the RenderTransform of the Rectangle.

segment.source: Finally, in the ManipulationDelta event handler, the position of the Rectangle is updated by using the TranslateTransform on the Delta property.
segment.target: Finally, in the ManipulationDelta event handler, the position of the Rectangle is updated by using the TranslateTransform on the Delta property.

segment.source: Routed events
segment.target: Routed events

segment.source: All of the pointer events, gesture events and manipulation events mentioned here are implemented as routed events.
segment.target: All of the pointer events, gesture events and manipulation events mentioned here are implemented as routed events.

segment.source: This means that the event can potentially be handled by objects other than the one that originally raised the event.
segment.target: This means that the event can potentially be handled by objects other than the one that originally raised the event.

segment.source: Successive parents in an object tree, such as the parent containers of a UIElement or the root Page of your app, can choose to handle these events even if the original element does not.
segment.target: Successive parents in an object tree, such as the parent containers of a UIElement or the root Page of your app, can choose to handle these events even if the original element does not.

segment.source: Conversely, any object that does handle the event can mark the event handled so that it no longer reaches any parent element.
segment.target: Conversely, any object that does handle the event can mark the event handled so that it no longer reaches any parent element.

segment.source: For more info about the routed event concept and how it affects how you write handlers for routed events, see Events and routed events overview.
segment.target: For more info about the routed event concept and how it affects how you write handlers for routed events, see Events and routed events overview.

segment.source: Dos and don'ts
segment.target: Dos and don'ts

segment.source: Design applications with touch interaction as the primary expected input method.
segment.target: Design applications with touch interaction as the primary expected input method.

segment.source: Provide visual feedback for interactions of all types (touch, pen, stylus, mouse, etc.)
segment.target: Provide visual feedback for interactions of all types (touch, pen, stylus, mouse, etc.)

segment.source: Optimize targeting by adjusting touch target size, contact geometry, scrubbing and rocking.
segment.target: Optimize targeting by adjusting touch target size, contact geometry, scrubbing and rocking.

segment.source: Optimize accuracy through the use of snap points and directional "rails".
segment.target: Optimize accuracy through the use of snap points and directional "rails".

segment.source: Provide tooltips and handles to help improve touch accuracy for tightly packed UI items.
segment.target: Provide tooltips and handles to help improve touch accuracy for tightly packed UI items.

segment.source: Don't use timed interactions whenever possible (example of appropriate use: touch and hold).
segment.target: Don't use timed interactions whenever possible (example of appropriate use: touch and hold).

segment.source: Don't use the number of fingers used to distinguish the manipulation whenever possible.
segment.target: Don't use the number of fingers used to distinguish the manipulation whenever possible.
